variables.description: Variable declaration and initialization in Java

examples.title: Basic variable declaration
examples.explanation: Java is statically typed, so variables must be declared with their type. Variables can be initialized at declaration or later.
examples.code:
String name = "John";
int age = 30;

examples.title: Multiple variable declaration
examples.explanation: Multiple variables of the same type can be declared in a single statement. This is less common in modern Java code.
examples.code: String firstName = "John", lastName = "Doe";

examples.title: Primitive Types
examples.explanation: Java has 8 primitive types: byte (8-bit), short (16-bit), int (32-bit), long (64-bit), float (32-bit), double (64-bit), char (16-bit), and boolean. They are stored by value.

examples.title: Wrapper Classes
examples.explanation: Each primitive type has a corresponding wrapper class (Byte, Short, Integer, Long, Float, Double, Character, Boolean) that provides methods and allows null values.

examples.title: Type Conversion
examples.explanation: Java performs automatic widening conversions (e.g., int to long) but requires explicit casting for narrowing conversions (e.g., double to int).

examples.title: Constant declaration
examples.explanation: The final keyword makes a variable constant. For class-level constants, static final is used. Constants are typically in UPPER_CASE.
examples.code:
final double PI = 3.14;
final String LANGUAGE = "Java";

examples.title: If statement
examples.explanation: If statements evaluate a boolean expression. The condition must be a boolean value, not a number like in some other languages.

examples.title: If-else statement
examples.explanation: The else block executes when the if condition is false. Java uses curly braces to define code blocks.

examples.title: Ternary operator
examples.explanation: The ternary operator is a shorthand for if-else. It returns one of two values based on a boolean condition.
examples.code: String status = age > 18 ? "Adult" : "Minor";

examples.title: Switch statement
examples.explanation: Switch statements compare a value against multiple cases. Java 12+ supports switch expressions. Break statements prevent fall-through.

examples.title: For loop
examples.explanation: Traditional for loops have initialization, condition, and increment/decrement. They're good for when you know the number of iterations.

examples.title: While loop
examples.explanation: While loops continue as long as the condition is true. The condition is checked before each iteration.

examples.title: For-each loop
examples.explanation: For-each loops iterate over arrays and collections. They're simpler and safer than traditional for loops for collections.

examples.title: Basic method
examples.explanation: Java methods must be declared within a class. They specify return type, name, parameters, and can throw exceptions.

examples.title: Method with multiple parameters
examples.explanation: Methods can take multiple parameters of different types. Parameters are passed by value in Java.

examples.title: Try-catch block
examples.explanation: Java uses try-catch blocks to handle exceptions. Checked exceptions must be caught or declared in the method signature.

examples.title: Try-catch-finally
examples.explanation: The finally block always executes, making it ideal for resource cleanup. Java 7+ introduced try-with-resources for automatic resource management.

examples.title: Class definition
examples.explanation: Java classes support encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism. Fields are typically private with public getters/setters.

examples.title: Array Declaration and Initialization
examples.explanation: Java arrays are fixed-length and can hold either primitives or objects. Arrays are zero-indexed and their length is fixed at creation.

examples.title: Array Operations
examples.explanation: Java provides several ways to work with arrays, including the Arrays utility class and System.arraycopy for efficient copying.

collections.description: Collections and data structures in Java

examples.title: Lists and Arrays
examples.explanation: Java provides various list implementations and array operations.

examples.title: Maps and Sets
examples.explanation: Java provides various Map and Set implementations.

examples.title: Custom Collections
examples.explanation: Java allows creating custom collections by implementing collection interfaces.

examples.title: Generic Classes and Methods
examples.explanation: Generics provide type safety and eliminate the need for casting. They are implemented using type erasure at runtime.

examples.title: Wildcards
examples.explanation: Wildcards provide flexibility when working with generic types. They can be upper-bounded or lower-bounded.

examples.title: Threads
examples.explanation: Java threads can be created by extending Thread or implementing Runnable. Threads share the same memory space.

examples.title: Synchronization
examples.explanation: Synchronization prevents multiple threads from accessing shared resources simultaneously.

examples.title: Executors and Futures
examples.explanation: The Executor framework provides a higher-level replacement for working directly with threads.

examples.title: Stream Operations
examples.explanation: Streams provide a functional approach to processing collections of data.

examples.title: Parallel Streams
examples.explanation: Parallel streams can improve performance for large datasets by utilizing multiple cores.

examples.title: Garbage Collection
examples.explanation: Java's garbage collector automatically manages memory by reclaiming objects that are no longer reachable.

examples.title: Memory Leaks
examples.explanation: Even with garbage collection, memory leaks can occur when objects are unintentionally kept reachable.

examples.title: Built-in Annotations
examples.explanation: Java provides several built-in annotations for common use cases like overriding methods, suppressing warnings, and marking deprecated code.

examples.title: Custom Annotations
examples.explanation: Java allows creating custom annotations with retention policies and target elements.

examples.title: Class Reflection
examples.explanation: Reflection allows examining and modifying the runtime behavior of classes, methods, and fields.

examples.title: Dynamic Method Invocation
examples.explanation: Reflection allows invoking methods and accessing fields dynamically at runtime.

examples.title: Module Declaration
examples.explanation: Java modules provide strong encapsulation and explicit dependencies between components.

examples.title: Module Usage
examples.explanation: Modules can be used to create modular applications with clear boundaries and dependencies.

examples.title: Native Method Declaration
examples.explanation: JNI allows Java code to call and be called by native applications and libraries written in other languages.

examples.title: Native Implementation
examples.explanation: Native methods are implemented in C/C++ and must follow JNI naming and type conventions.

examples.title: Basic Serialization
examples.explanation: Java's serialization mechanism allows objects to be converted to a byte stream and reconstructed later.

examples.title: Externalizable Interface
examples.explanation: The Externalizable interface provides more control over the serialization process than Serializable.

examples.title: Console Input/Output
examples.explanation: Java provides System.in, System.out, and System.err for basic console I/O. Scanner is commonly used for reading input.

examples.title: Formatted Output
examples.explanation: Java provides printf and format methods for formatted output using format specifiers.

examples.title: File I/O
examples.explanation: Java provides various classes for file I/O operations, including reading and writing text and binary files.

http.description: HTTP client and server in Java

examples.title: HttpURLConnection
examples.explanation: Java's built-in HttpURLConnection class provides basic HTTP client functionality. It's part of the standard library but can be verbose to use.

examples.title: HttpClient (Java 11+)
examples.explanation: Java 11 introduced a new HttpClient API that provides a more modern and flexible way to make HTTP requests.

examples.title: Spring WebClient
examples.explanation: Spring's WebClient is a reactive HTTP client that provides a fluent API and supports both synchronous and asynchronous operations.

examples.title: Spring Boot REST Controller
examples.explanation: Spring Boot makes it easy to create RESTful web services with its @RestController annotation and various HTTP method annotations.

examples.title: Basic String Operations
examples.explanation: Java's String class provides a rich set of string operations. Strings are immutable in Java.

examples.title: Regular Expressions
examples.explanation: Java's Pattern and Matcher classes provide regular expression functionality.

date_time.description: Date and time handling in Java

examples.title: Basic Date/Time Operations
examples.explanation: Java 8+ provides the java.time package for comprehensive date and time handling.

examples.title: JDBC Basics
examples.explanation: Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) provides a standard API for database operations.

examples.title: Transactions
examples.explanation: JDBC supports transactions for ensuring data consistency.

examples.title: Hibernate ORM
examples.explanation: Hibernate is a popular ORM framework that simplifies database operations.

json_xml.description: JSON and XML handling in Java

examples.title: JSON Processing
examples.explanation: Java provides several libraries for JSON processing, including Jackson and Gson.

examples.title: XML Processing
examples.explanation: Java provides several APIs for XML processing, including DOM, SAX, and JAXB.

command_line.description: Command line argument handling in Java

examples.title: Basic Argument Parsing
examples.explanation: Java provides basic command line argument handling through the main method's args parameter.

examples.title: Apache Commons CLI
examples.explanation: Apache Commons CLI provides a more robust command line argument parsing.

examples.title: Environment Variables
examples.explanation: Java provides access to environment variables and system properties.

examples.title: JUnit Basics
examples.explanation: JUnit is the standard testing framework for Java.

examples.title: Mocking with Mockito
examples.explanation: Mockito is a popular mocking framework for Java.

examples.title: SLF4J and Logback
examples.explanation: SLF4J is a logging facade, and Logback is a popular implementation.

examples.title: Log Configuration
examples.explanation: Logback configuration for different appenders and log rotation.
examples.code:
<!-- logback.xml -->
<configuration>
    <appender name="CONSOLE" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">
        <encoder>
            <pattern>%d{HH:mm:ss.SSS} [%thread] %-5level %logger{36} - %msg%n</pattern>
        </encoder>
    </appender>
    
    <appender name="FILE" class="ch.qos.logback.core.rolling.RollingFileAppender">
        <file>logs/myapp.log</file>
        <rollingPolicy class="ch.qos.logback.core.rolling.TimeBasedRollingPolicy">
            <fileNamePattern>logs/myapp.%d{yyyy-MM-dd}.log</fileNamePattern>
            <maxHistory>30</maxHistory>
        </rollingPolicy>
        <encoder>
            <pattern>%d{yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSS} [%thread] %-5level %logger{36} - %msg%n</pattern>
        </encoder>
    </appender>
    
    <root level="INFO">
        <appender-ref ref="CONSOLE" />
        <appender-ref ref="FILE" />
    </root>
</configuration>

package_management.description: Package and dependency management in Java

examples.title: Maven Basics
examples.explanation: Maven is a popular build and dependency management tool for Java.
examples.code:
<!-- pom.xml -->
<project>
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
    <groupId>com.example</groupId>
    <artifactId>myapp</artifactId>
    <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
    
    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.springframework</groupId>
            <artifactId>spring-web</artifactId>
            <version>5.3.0</version>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.core</groupId>
            <artifactId>jackson-databind</artifactId>
            <version>2.12.0</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>
    
    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.8.1</version>
                <configuration>
                    <source>11</source>
                    <target>11</target>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>

examples.title: Gradle Basics
examples.explanation: Gradle is another popular build tool that uses a Groovy-based DSL.

examples.title: Module System
examples.explanation: Java 9+ introduced a module system for better encapsulation and dependency management.

gui_development.description: Building desktop GUIs in Java using Swing and JavaFX. Swing provides lightweight components with good portability, while JavaFX offers modern UI features and better styling capabilities.

examples.title: Basic Swing Window with Button
examples.explanation: A simple Swing application with a button that updates a label when clicked.

examples.title: JavaFX Basic Window
examples.explanation: A JavaFX window with a button and a label. JavaFX apps require launching via the Application class.

examples.title: Swing Table Example (JTable)
examples.explanation: Using JTable to show tabular data in Swing.

examples.title: JavaFX Canvas Drawing
examples.explanation: JavaFX allows drawing on a Canvas node using a GraphicsContext.

examples.title: Swing Dialogs (JOptionPane)
examples.explanation: Swing provides easy-to-use modal dialogs for input, confirmation, and messages.

examples.title: Swing Layouts (BorderLayout and GridLayout)
examples.explanation: Swing has several layout managers. Heres an example using BorderLayout and GridLayout.

examples.title: JavaFX Scene Switching
examples.explanation: JavaFX supports swapping between scenes or updating root nodes to simulate navigation.

examples.title: JavaFX Styling with CSS
examples.explanation: You can apply styles in JavaFX using external or inline CSS.

examples.title: JavaFX with FXML
examples.explanation: FXML separates UI layout from business logic, similar to HTML/CSS for the web.

examples.title: FXML File
examples.explanation: FXML file associated with the JavaFX application. Should be saved as 'sample.fxml' in the same package.
examples.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<?import javafx.scene.control.*?>
<?import javafx.scene.layout.VBox?>

<VBox xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml"
      fx:controller="Controller" spacing="10" alignment="CENTER">
    <Label text="Hello FXML!" />
    <Button text="Click Me" onAction="#handleClick" />
</VBox>

examples.title: Controller.java (for FXML)
examples.explanation: The controller class defines logic triggered by FXML-defined UI elements.

examples.title: MVC Pattern (JavaFX)
examples.explanation: Organize JavaFX app with separate Model, View (FXML), and Controller.

examples.title: JavaFX Media Player
examples.explanation: Play video/audio files using JavaFX MediaPlayer.

examples.title: Packaging with Maven
examples.explanation: Use Maven to manage dependencies and package your JavaFX app.
examples.code:
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
  <groupId>com.example</groupId>
  <artifactId>javafx-gui</artifactId>
  <version>1.0</version>
  <properties>
    <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
    <javafx.version>20</javafx.version>
  </properties>
  <dependencies>
    <dependency>
      <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId>
      <artifactId>javafx-controls</artifactId>
      <version>${javafx.version}</version>
    </dependency>
  </dependencies>
</project>

examples.title: Deploying with JLink
examples.explanation: Use JLink to create a custom runtime image for distribution (Java 9+).
examples.code:
jlink \
  --module-path $JAVA_HOME/jmods:target/libs \
  --add-modules your.module.name \
  --output myapp-runtime
